title: Installation issue: openssh
body:
<!-- Thanks for taking the time to report this build failure. To proceed with the report please:

1. Title the issue "Installation issue: <name-of-the-package>".
2. Provide the information required below.

We encourage you to try, as much as possible, to reduce your problem to the minimal example that still reproduces the issue. That would help us a lot in fixing it quickly and effectively! -->

#22115 added `openssh` as a dependency to the `openmpi` package.  `openssh` fails to build on my system, which breaks multiple upstream packages that depend on `openmpi`.  

The workaround is to use an external ssh.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ spack install openssh
```

The issue likely only appears if the user database is managed by NIS.

### Additional information

OpenSSH builds successfully, but during install runs `ssh-keygen -A`.  That fails with:

```
No user exists for uid 1175
```

The offending code is:

```
     pw = getpwuid(getuid());
     if (!pw)
         fatal("No user exists for uid %lu", (u_long)getuid());
```

The root cause appears to be that `ssh-keygen` is using `libcrypto.so` from the `openssl` package via RPATH, but NIS wants the system `libcrypto.so`.  

```
$ ldd ssh-keygen
...
	libcrypto.so.1.1 => /home/smcmillan/git/smcmillan/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos8-haswell/gcc-8.3.1/openssl-1.1.1k-5kyfnh3x5k6hxkttqgcsysaw5ayeykoh/lib/libcrypto.so.1.1 (0x00007f34b6371000)
...
```

If I modify the `ssh-keygen` binary with `chrpath` to remove that RPATH entry, then it uses the system `libcrypto.so` and  succeeds.  This looks identical to https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1877730.
